line_2: Bless your Conceits! must I believe,

line_1: Or own those Truths they cannot well conceive.
line_2: Oft Seamen tell, but few the Tale believe,

line_1: So have I seen (who has not, may conceive,)
line_2: So doth it wanton birds of peace bereave,

line_1: Than the gay Idler knows, or Fools conceive:
line_2: One Hour thus spent, more solid Joys shall give,

line_1: From fatal symptoms if I right conceive,
line_2: This voice to murmur, and this breast to heave.

line_1: Such as the souls of Cowards might conceive,
line_2: And form'd like Tyrants, Tyrants would believe.

line_1: All States can reach it, and all Heads conceive;
line_2: Take Nature's path, and mad Opinion's leave,

line_1: Who ask and reason thus, will scarce conceive
line_2: God gives enough while he has more to give:

line_1: That these, their misfortunes, they humbly conceive,
line_2: Arise not from dulness, as some folks believe,

line_1: Thus the rankest absurdity brain can conceive,
line_2: Superstition imposes, and crowds will believe!

line_1: No Muse can paint 'em, nor no Heart conceive:
line_2: But O! what Griefs attend the parting Leave,

line_1: What ideas can such low-bred creatures conceive,
line_2: Says Mrs. Noworthy, and laught in her sleeve.

line_1: (Out-cast of Mortal Race!) can We conceive
line_2: The arbitrary Lash, to bend, to grieve;

line_1: Ev'n the Dead hear; the Lab'ring Graves Conceive,
line_2: And the swoln Clod in Picture seems to heave:

line_1: Because we are unable to conceive,
line_2: How unembody'd souls can act, and live,
